evaluation.tip: Be more specific about which concepts are hardest and share your feelings about the pressure you're under; this helps the professor tailor support.

user_replies: most of the items are hard, if you can can I get an extension for it
but I know I can do it I just think I don't have enough time

conversation_context.content: Hey there! I just finished grading those quizzes and... honestly, I'm a bit worried about you.

Hey! So... I know this might not be the convo you wanna have right now, but I just finished grading the latest batch and I gotta ask - how are you doing? Like *really* doing?

Those last two quizzes hit pretty hard, huh?

Yeah, I can see that. 35 on the Data Structures quiz and 28 on the Algorithms one… that’s a rough combo. I’m not trying to pile on—just being straight with you: if the midterm goes the same way, the math gets real ugly real fast.

So, what’s been the hardest part? Is it the concepts themselves, or is it more like “I’m staring at the problem and my brain just freezes”?
most of the items are hard, if you can can I get an extension for it

I hear you—those quizzes were brutal, and I totally get why you’d want more time. But here’s the thing: the midterm’s locked in for two weeks from now (department schedule, can’t move it), and it’s worth 30% of your grade. If we push anything back, we’re just squeezing the prep time even more, and that could make the midterm even tougher.

Instead of an extension, how about we figure out a game plan together? Like, what’s the ONE topic that’s eating you alive the most right now—linked lists, Big-O, sorting algos? If we can nail down the biggest pain point, we can tackle it first and build some momentum.
but I know I can do it I just think I don't have enough time

I totally believe you *can* do it—I've seen you get stuff when it clicks. But here's the real talk: we’re two weeks out from the midterm, and right now the numbers say you're sitting at about a 45 overall. That’s not a “maybe I’ll catch up” zone; that’s “I might have to retake the whole course” territory. I don’t want that for you, and I bet you don’t either.

So let’s flip the script on “not enough time.” Instead of asking for more calendar days, let’s steal back the hours you’re already spending but maybe not using super efficiently. Quick reality-check: how many hours this week did you spend on CS stuff that wasn’t actually moving the needle (scrolling notes you already skimmed, re-watching lectures at 1.5× while kinda zoning out, etc.)?
